examples.title: Sending Money to a Friend Abroad
examples.scenario: Sarah wants to send $500 to her friend John who lives in Germany. She initiates a wire transfer from her Chase Bank account to John's Deutsche Bank account.

steps.description: Sarah logs into her bank's mobile app and enters John's IBAN (DE89370400440532013000), amount ($500), and reason ('Birthday gift'). She submits the transfer request.
steps.technical: Chase Bank creates a pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer Initiation) message with Sarah as Debtor, John as Creditor, and Deutsche Bank as Creditor Agent.

steps.description: Chase Bank validates the format and sends an immediate confirmation to Sarah that the payment has been accepted for processing.
steps.technical: pain.002 (Customer Payment Status Report) sent to Sarah with status ACTC (Accepted Technical Validation) or ACCP (Accepted Customer Profile).

steps.description: Chase Bank validates Sarah's account has sufficient funds, converts the pain.001 into a pacs.008 (FICredit Transfer) message, and sends it through the SWIFT network to Deutsche Bank.
steps.technical: pacs.008 message includes all payment details, unique UETR (transaction reference), currency conversion instructions if needed, and routing information.

steps.description: Deutsche Bank receives the pacs.008, validates the IBAN, converts USD to EUR at the daily rate, and credits €475.20 to John's account.
steps.technical: Deutsche Bank sends a pacs.002 (Payment Status Report) back to Chase confirming successful acceptance. John's account is credited and he receives a notification.

steps.description: At end of day, both banks generate account statements. Sarah sees -$500 debit, John sees +€475.20 credit. Banks settle via correspondent banking arrangements.
steps.technical: camt.053 (Bank to Customer Statement) messages are generated for both Sarah and John showing the transaction details in their respective account statements.

possible_errors.result: Payment would be rejected and returned to Sarah

possible_errors.scenario: If Sarah only had $450 in her account
possible_errors.result: Chase would reject the payment before sending

possible_errors.scenario: If transaction was flagged for compliance review
possible_errors.result: Payment would be held pending investigation

key_takeaways: Cross-border payments involve multiple message types
Currency conversion happens at beneficiary bank
Each payment has unique UETR for tracking
Multiple banks may be involved in routing

examples.title: Receiving Your Monthly Salary
examples.scenario: Emily works at TechCorp and receives her monthly salary of $5,000 via direct deposit. TechCorp uses Wells Fargo, Emily banks with Bank of America.

steps.description: TechCorp's payroll system generates a batch file with 500 employees' salary payments. Emily is one of them. The file is sent to Wells Fargo on the 1st of the month.
steps.technical: pain.001 message with 500 credit transfer instructions. Each instruction contains employee details, bank routing numbers, account numbers, and amounts. BulkPayment = true.

steps.description: Wells Fargo validates TechCorp has sufficient funds ($2.5M), splits the batch by destination banks, and submits to ACH network. Emily's payment is routed to Bank of America.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.008 messages are created, grouped by receiving banks. Each message contains relevant credit transfers. Sent through ACH network with value date = next business day.
key_fields: Creditor Agent: Bank of America routing number

steps.description: Bank of America receives ACH file overnight, validates account numbers, and credits Emily's account at 6 AM on the 2nd. Emily receives mobile notification.
steps.technical: Bank of America sends pacs.002 acknowledgment to Wells Fargo. Simultaneously generates camt.054 (Debit/Credit Notification) for Emily's account.

steps.description: Emily checks her mobile app and sees $5,000 deposited with description 'TechCorp Inc. - January 2026 Salary'. Her new balance is $12,345.67.
steps.technical: Mobile app displays data from camt.054 notification. At month-end, full statement (camt.053) will include this transaction with all details.

possible_errors.scenario: If employee account number was wrong
possible_errors.result: ACH return, payment sent back to TechCorp

possible_errors.scenario: If Emily had closed her account
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected and returned to employer
Entire batch rejected by Wells Fargo

key_takeaways: Payroll uses bulk/batch payments for efficiency
ACH is the clearing system for domestic US payments
camt.054 provides real-time credit notifications
Value date may differ from submission date

examples.title: When a Payment Bounces Back
examples.scenario: Alice tries to send £200 to Bob to pay for concert tickets, but she accidentally enters the wrong account number. The payment is rejected and returned to her account.

steps.description: Alice wants to send £200 to Bob's account ending in 4567, but she accidentally types 4568. She submits the payment through online banking.
steps.technical: Barclays creates pain.001 with incorrect account number (4568 instead of 4567). Payment instructions appear valid at origination.

steps.description: Barclays validates Alice has funds, debits her account £200, and sends the payment through UK's Faster Payments Service to HSBC.
steps.technical: pacs.008 message sent through FPS with the incorrect account number. Alice's account shows immediate debit.

steps.description: HSBC receives the payment and performs validation. Account GB29HBUK40127612344568 does not exist in their system. Automated system rejects the payment.
steps.technical: HSBC generates pacs.004 (Payment Return) message with reason code AC01 (Incorrect Account Number). Payment is returned to Barclays within minutes.

steps.description: Barclays receives the pacs.004 return, credits Alice's account £200, and sends her a notification explaining the payment failed due to incorrect account number.
steps.technical: Alice's account is re-credited. camt.054 notification sent to Alice's mobile banking. She can see both the original debit and the returned credit in her transaction history.

steps.description: Alice contacts Bob, gets the correct account number (4567), and successfully sends the payment again. This time it's accepted and Bob receives the funds.
steps.technical: New pain.001 → pacs.008 flow with correct account. HSBC accepts with pacs.002 (ACCP status). Payment completes successfully.

possible_errors.result: Similar return with AC04 reason code

key_takeaways: Payment returns use pacs.004 message type
Return reason codes (like AC01) explain why payment failed
Modern payment systems return funds quickly (minutes to hours)
Always verify account details before sending
Original payment reference is maintained in returns

examples.title: Company Paying Multiple Suppliers
examples.scenario: MegaMart needs to pay 50 different suppliers for goods delivered in December. Amounts range from $1,000 to $50,000. They use their corporate banking platform to submit a bulk payment file.

steps.description: Accounts Payable team exports payment file from ERP system containing 50 supplier payments totaling $875,000. Each payment includes invoice numbers for reconciliation.
steps.technical: pain.001 message with 50 credit transfer instructions. Each includes structured remittance information with invoice references. Batch booking requested for efficiency.

steps.description: AP Manager logs into JPMorgan's CorporateConnect platform, uploads the payment file, reviews summary, and approves the batch. Dual authorization is required.
steps.technical: Portal validates pain.001 format, checks account balance ($900,000 available), applies corporate payment rules, and queues for second approver.

steps.description: After second approval, JPMorgan debits MegaMart's account $875,000, splits payments by destination bank and payment method (ACH vs Wire), and sends to clearing systems.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.008 messages created: 45 payments via ACH (smaller amounts), 5 payments via Wire (larger/urgent). Each grouped by settlement method.

steps.description: Receiving banks process incoming payments. Wire transfers settle same-day, ACH payments settle next business day. Each supplier receives credit notification with invoice details.
steps.technical: Each receiving bank sends pacs.002 acknowledgment. Suppliers receive camt.054 notifications showing payment amount and which invoices are being paid.
key_fields: Settlement Date: Based on payment method

steps.description: Suppliers' AR systems auto-reconcile payments against open invoices using structured remittance data. MegaMart receives confirmation that all 50 payments were successful.
steps.technical: MegaMart receives pain.002 status report showing all payments accepted. Both parties receive camt.053 statements showing all transaction details for month-end reconciliation.

possible_errors.scenario: If one supplier's account number was incorrect
possible_errors.result: That payment returned via pacs.004, other 49 succeed

possible_errors.scenario: If batch was accidentally submitted twice

key_takeaways: Bulk payments are processed as single batch for efficiency
Structured remittance info enables auto-reconciliation
Payment methods (ACH/Wire) affect settlement speed
Corporate payments often require dual authorization
Status reports track success/failure of each payment

examples.title: Understanding Your Bank Statement
examples.scenario: Michael wants to reconcile his business checking account for December. He downloads his electronic bank statement in ISO 20022 format to import into his accounting software.

steps.description: On January 1st, Michael logs into Citibank's business banking portal and requests his December 2025 statement in ISO 20022 XML format for his accounting software.
steps.technical: Portal generates a camt.053 (Bank to Customer Statement) message containing all December transactions for Michael's account.

steps.description: The statement shows opening balance, all debits and credits for the month, and closing balance. Michael sees 156 transactions: 89 credits (customer payments) and 67 debits (supplier payments, fees).
steps.technical: camt.053 contains structured entries. Each entry has Credit/Debit indicator, amount, value date, booking date, transaction reference, and counterparty details.

steps.description: Michael clicks on a large credit entry ($12,500 from ClientCorp on Dec 15). The statement shows full details: who sent it, what invoices it paid, and when it settled.
steps.technical: Each statement entry contains: Amount, Value Date, Booking Date, Debtor/Creditor info, Remittance Information (invoice refs), Bank Transaction Code, and unique Entry Reference.

steps.description: Michael imports the camt.053 XML file into QuickBooks. The software automatically matches $450,000 of transactions to open invoices using the remittance information.
steps.technical: Accounting software parses camt.053 XML, extracts remittance references, and matches to AR/AP. Bank Transaction Codes help categorize (e.g., PMNT=payment, FEES=bank fees, INT=interest).

steps.description: After reviewing the 11 unmatched items (mostly bank fees and one unknown credit), Michael completes reconciliation. His accounting system shows $52,167.25 matches the bank's closing balance.
steps.technical: Final reconciliation confirms all transactions accounted for. camt.053's closing balance becomes opening balance for January statement (camt.053 continuity).

possible_errors.scenario: Balance mismatch between books and bank
possible_errors.result: Investigation needed to find missing/duplicate entry

key_takeaways: camt.053 is the ISO 20022 format for bank statements
Statements include structured transaction details for auto-reconciliation
Value date shows when funds are available
Remittance info links payments to invoices
Electronic statements integrate directly with accounting software

examples.title: Canceling a Wrong Payment (Payment Recall)
examples.scenario: TechSupply's AP team accidentally sends $50,000 to the wrong vendor (WrongVendor LLC instead of CorrectVendor Inc.). The error is discovered 2 hours later. They need to request a payment recall before funds are withdrawn.

steps.description: TechSupply realizes they sent $50,000 to the wrong supplier account. They immediately contact their bank to recall the payment.
steps.technical: Original pacs.008 was sent with incorrect creditor account

steps.description: Bank of America sends a camt.056 CustomerPaymentCancellationRequest to Wells Fargo requesting the return of funds.
steps.technical: camt.056 references the original pacs.008 message ID

steps.description: Wells Fargo checks if funds are available in beneficiary's account.
steps.technical: Bank verifies account balance and checks for holds

steps.description: Wells Fargo accepts the recall and sends funds back via pacs.004.
steps.technical: pacs.004 PaymentReturn with full or partial amount

steps.description: Wells Fargo sends camt.029 confirming the recall was successful.
Bank of America credits TechSupply's account with the returned funds.
Wells Fargo cannot return funds (spent, account closed, or beneficiary refuses).
steps.technical: camt.029 with Status = RJCT and reason code

steps.description: Bank of America informs TechSupply that the recall failed. Legal action may be needed.

possible_errors.scenario: If payment was a duplicate transaction
possible_errors.result: Recall justified under DUPL reason code

possible_errors.scenario: If payment suspected to be fraudulent
possible_errors.result: Urgent recall with FRAD reason code, higher priority

possible_errors.scenario: If WrongVendor already withdrew the funds
possible_errors.result: Recall denied, must pursue legal recovery

key_takeaways: Payment recalls use camt.056 (Cancellation Request) message
Success depends on timing - before beneficiary withdraws funds
camt.029 provides investigation outcome
Reason codes (CUST, DUPL, FRAD) explain cancellation cause
Time is critical - faster action increases recall success rate

examples.title: Splitting Dinner Bill with Instant Payment
examples.scenario: Lisa and David have dinner together. David pays the $120 restaurant bill with his credit card. Lisa sends her half ($60) to David instantly using her banking app's real-time payment feature (RTP network).

steps.description: While still at the restaurant, Lisa opens her Chime app, selects 'Send Money', enters David's phone number (linked to his Venmo account), amount $60, and note 'Dinner split'. Taps 'Send Now'.
steps.technical: Chime creates instant payment instruction (pain.001 variant for RTP). Payment is flagged for immediate settlement via RTP network rather than next-day ACH.
key_fields: Creditor Lookup: Phone number â†’ Venmo account

steps.description: Chime checks Lisa's account balance and looks up David's phone number in the RTP directory to find his receiving bank.
steps.technical: Pre-validation before sending pacs.008. Checks: sufficient funds, valid recipient lookup, account status.
steps.decision_question: Does Lisa have sufficient funds and is David's account valid?

steps.description: Chime validates Lisa has $60 available, debits her account instantly (balance updates in real-time), and sends payment through The Clearing House's RTP network to Synchrony (Venmo's bank partner).
steps.technical: pacs.008 instant variant sent via RTP rail. Payment is irrevocable once sent. Settlement happens in real-time between banks - no batch processing.

steps.description: Within 5 seconds, Synchrony receives the RTP payment, credits David's Venmo balance $60, and sends push notification. David sees the money immediately - can spend it right away.
steps.technical: Synchrony sends instant pacs.002 acknowledgment (ACSC - Accepted Settlement Completed). Funds are immediately available - no holding period.

steps.description: Lisa's Chime app updates balance: -$60 with timestamp 7:23 PM. Transaction shows as 'Sent to David - Dinner split'.
steps.technical: camt.054 debit notification in real-time. Lisa's available balance immediately reduced.

steps.description: David's Venmo app shows +$60 with Lisa's note 'Dinner split' at same timestamp. He can spend it immediately.
steps.technical: camt.054 credit notification. Funds immediately available for use.

steps.description: Chime's validation fails. Either Lisa's balance is only $50 (insufficient funds) or David's phone number isn't linked to any RTP-enabled account.
steps.technical: pain.002 payment status report returned immediately. No funds are debited. Clear error code provided.
key_fields: Reason: AM04 (Insufficient Funds) or AC01 (Invalid Account)
Action: Retry with different amount or recipient

steps.description: Lisa's Chime app shows error message. If insufficient funds, she can transfer from savings or send smaller amount. If invalid recipient, she asks David for correct phone/email.
steps.technical: User-friendly error displayed. Suggested actions based on error code. No funds lost or held.

possible_errors.scenario: If Lisa only had $50 in her account
If David's phone number wasn't linked to any account
possible_errors.result: Payment fails immediately with 'recipient not found'

possible_errors.scenario: If RTP network was experiencing downtime
possible_errors.result: Payment fails, Lisa receives error to retry later

key_takeaways: Instant payments settle in seconds, not days
RTP (Real-Time Payments) is US instant payment network
Funds are immediately available - no holding period
Payments are irrevocable once sent (can't be recalled)
Similar systems: SEPA Instant (EU), Faster Payments (UK), FedNow (US)

examples.title: Setting Up Gym Membership Direct Debit
examples.scenario: Emma signs up for FitLife Gym membership at €49.99/month. She authorizes the gym to automatically debit her bank account monthly via SEPA Direct Debit. The gym needs to collect payment on the 1st of each month.

steps.description: John fills out the gym membership form and authorizes monthly direct debit payments of $49.99.
steps.technical: Customer provides bank details and signs mandate authorization

steps.description: FitLife Gym sends the mandate information to their bank for processing.
Wells Fargo sends the mandate to John's bank (Chase) for verification and acceptance.
steps.decision_question: Does debtor's bank accept the mandate?

steps.description: Chase Bank verifies John's account and accepts the direct debit mandate.
Wells Fargo notifies FitLife Gym that the mandate has been successfully set up.
John receives confirmation that his gym membership is active and payments will begin next month.
Chase Bank rejects the mandate (insufficient funds, account closed, or customer opt-out).
steps.technical: pain.012 with status RJCT and reason code

steps.description: Wells Fargo informs FitLife Gym that the mandate was rejected.
FitLife Gym contacts John to provide alternative payment details or resolve the issue.

possible_errors.scenario: If mandate was never signed or doesn't exist
possible_errors.result: Direct debit rejected, funds not collected

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma requests refund within 8 weeks
possible_errors.result: Bank returns funds to Emma, charges FitLife

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma only has €30 in account
possible_errors.result: Direct debit bounces due to insufficient funds

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma blocked direct debits on her account
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected - account blocked for direct debits

key_takeaways: Direct debits require signed mandate before collection
SEPA has 3 sequence types: FRST (first), RCUR (recurring), FNAL (final)
First collection needs 5 days pre-notification, recurring needs 2
Debtors can request refund within 8 weeks (consumer protection)
pain.008 initiates direct debit, pacs.003 is interbank message

examples.title: International Trade Payment via Letter of Credit
examples.scenario: GlobalTech imports $500,000 worth of electronics from China. To mitigate risk, they use a Letter of Credit (LC). Payment involves multiple correspondent banks, currency conversion (USD to CNY), and compliance checks.

steps.description: GlobalTech requests JPMorgan to issue LC for $500,000 in favor of ShenZhen Electronics. LC conditions: payment upon proof of shipment (Bill of Lading). Expiry: 90 days.
steps.technical: Trade finance process begins. LC issued as guarantee - JPMorgan commits to pay if conditions met. Not yet an ISO 20022 payment message.
steps.message_type: LC issuance (SWIFT MT700 / moving to ISO 20022 tsmt messages)
key_fields: Required Documents: Bill of Lading, Invoice, Packing List

steps.description: ShenZhen ships electronics via cargo ship, obtains Bill of Lading, and presents documents to Bank of China proving shipment occurred per LC terms. Bank of China validates documents.
steps.technical: Documentary collection process. Bank of China verifies all LC conditions met. Once satisfied, they request payment from JPMorgan.

steps.description: JPMorgan validates documents, approves payment. Routes $500,000 to Bank of China via correspondent banks. Path: JPMorgan → HSBC Hong Kong (correspondent) → Bank of China. Converts USD to CNY.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.009 (FI Credit Transfer) messages. First: JPMorgan to HSBC (USD). Second: HSBC to Bank of China (converted to CNY at spot rate ~7.2, = ¥3,600,000).

steps.description: JPMorgan debits GlobalTech's account $500,000 + $150 wire fees. HSBC settles using nostro account with Bank of China. Bank of China credits ShenZhen's account ¥3,600,000.
steps.technical: Settlement happens via nostro/vostro accounts. Each bank sends pacs.002 acknowledgments confirming their leg. Complex multi-hop payment complete.

steps.description: GlobalTech receives statement showing -$500,150. ShenZhen receives statement showing +¥3,600,000. JPMorgan and Bank of China exchange MT950/camt.053 statements confirming all aspects of trade.
steps.technical: camt.053 statements generated for all parties. Includes references to LC, Bill of Lading number, and full payment chain for audit trail.

possible_errors.scenario: If documents don't match LC terms exactly
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected, discrepancies must be resolved

possible_errors.scenario: If compliance flags parties for sanctions screening
If currency conversion fails or rate expires
possible_errors.result: Payment delayed until FX rate confirmed

key_takeaways: Trade payments often involve multiple intermediary banks
pacs.009 is used for financial institution to financial institution transfers
Correspondent banks facilitate cross-border settlement
Currency conversion happens at intermediary or beneficiary bank
Letters of Credit mitigate risk in international trade

examples.title: Fraud Detection and Payment Block
examples.scenario: CompromisedCorp's accounts payable system is hacked. Fraudster initiates a $250,000 wire transfer to an overseas account. Wells Fargo's fraud detection AI flags the transaction as highly suspicious and blocks it before sending.

steps.description: At 2:00 AM, fraudster uses stolen credentials to access CompromisedCorp's banking portal, creates payment to unknown overseas account for $250,000 with generic description 'Invoice payment'.
steps.technical: pain.001 generated with red flags: unusual time (2 AM), first-time beneficiary, high amount, tax haven destination, vague remittance info.

steps.description: Wells Fargo's AI analyzes payment against fraud models. Score: 98/100 risk. Flags: Off-hours, new beneficiary, high amount, destination country, atypical pattern for CompromisedCorp.
steps.technical: Payment enters fraud queue before converting to pacs.008. AI triggers immediate hold. Compliance team alerted. Payment status = PENDING REVIEW.
steps.decision_question: Does the customer confirm the payment is fraudulent?

steps.description: At 8:30 AM, compliance team calls CompromisedCorp's CFO to verify the $250,000 payment. CFO is unaware, confirms no such payment authorized. Identifies as fraud attempt.
steps.technical: Customer confirms unauthorized. Wells Fargo generates pacs.002 rejection with reason code AG01 (Transaction Forbidden). Payment never leaves the bank.

steps.description: Wells Fargo's fraud team documents incident, files Suspicious Activity Report (SAR), forces password reset for CompromisedCorp's accounts, and recommends security audit.
steps.technical: Internal incident case created. Regulatory reporting triggered (FinCEN SAR). Additional monitoring placed on account. No funds lost.

steps.description: CompromisedCorp receives notification via camt.054 that payment was blocked for fraud. They investigate their systems, discover malware, and engage security firm to remediate.
steps.technical: camt.054 debit notification with status 'Blocked - Fraud Detection'. Customer grateful payment stopped. Implements stronger controls (MFA, IP whitelisting, transaction limits).

steps.description: Compliance team contacts CFO who confirms the payment is legitimate - it's a pre-approved vendor payment for a new overseas supplier. Payment cleared for processing.
steps.technical: Customer provides verification. Payment released from fraud queue. Converts to pacs.008 for interbank transmission.

steps.description: Offshore Bank receives and processes the payment, credits the beneficiary account, and sends confirmation back to Wells Fargo.
steps.technical: pacs.002 with ACCP status confirms successful settlement. Funds credited to beneficiary.

steps.description: CompromisedCorp receives camt.054 notification confirming the payment was successfully sent. Note added to account for future similar payments to this vendor.
steps.technical: camt.054 debit notification confirms successful payment. White-listed vendor for future transactions to avoid fraud holds.

possible_errors.scenario: Transaction forbidden (as shown in fraud case)
If additional information needed for AML

key_takeaways: Banks use AI/ML to detect fraud in real-time
High-risk payments are blocked before funds leave the bank
AG01 error code indicates transaction forbidden (fraud/compliance)
Regulatory reporting (SARs) required for suspected fraud
Multi-factor authentication and transaction limits prevent fraud

examples.title: Opening a Corporate Investment Account
examples.scenario: TechStart Inc wants to open a new investment account to manage its surplus cash. They send a digital instruction to their Global Custodian Bank.

steps.description: TechStart submits a request to open a 'Surplus Cash USD' account.
steps.technical: acmt.001 (Account Opening Instruction) sent with account details, currency (USD), and settlement instructions.

steps.description: GCB processes the request, performs KYC, opens account 88990011, and confirms.
steps.technical: acmt.002 (Account Details Confirmation) sent back with the new Account ID.

key_takeaways: acmt messages automate account lifecycle
acmt.002 confirms the action

examples.title: Updating Corporate Address
examples.scenario: Moving Co moves its HQ to Lyon and needs to update its address on all banking accounts.

steps.technical: acmt.003 (Account Modification Instruction) with new postal address.

steps.description: Bank validates the request and updates the customer master data.
steps.technical: acmt.002 sent to confirm the modification is complete.

key_takeaways: acmt.003 handles updates to static data

examples.title: Closing an Inactive Account
examples.scenario: A project account is no longer needed. The Treasury Manager instructs the bank to close it and sweep remaining funds.

steps.description: Sends instruction to close account DE55...99.
steps.technical: acmt.019 (Account Closing Request) - *Note: Using acmt.003 or specific closing msg if available, usually acmt.019 in newer versions or acmt.003 with closing indicator.* Let's use acmt.003 for broad compatibility or check defs. acmt.019 is Closing Request.

key_takeaways: Maintenance messages handle closure too

examples.title: Technical Message Rejection
examples.scenario: A FinTech sends a payment file with malformed XML. The clearing system rejects it immediately.

steps.description: Sends a payment file but forgets a closing tag.
Gateway validator fails to parse file.
steps.technical: admi.002 (Message Reject) sent. Reason: Parsing Error.

key_takeaways: admi.002 is the ISO 20022 'NAK'

examples.title: Regulatory Reporting for Large Transfer
examples.scenario: BigBank processes a €10M cross-border trade. Regulatory rules require reporting this to the Central Bank.

steps.description: System automatically generates a report for the high-value transaction.

key_takeaways: auth messages are for regulators

examples.title: Intraday Liquidity Check
examples.scenario: At 2 PM, the Treasurer needs to know available cash to fund a sudden deal.

steps.technical: camt.060 (Account Reporting Request) sent asking for camt.052.

steps.description: Chase sends back the current positions.
steps.technical: camt.052 (Bank to Customer Account Report) showing intraday balance.

key_takeaways: camt.052 gives real-time visibility

examples.title: Expecting a Large Deposit
examples.scenario: Hedge Fund expects £50M from an investor and wants to warn the bank to avoid compliance delays.
key_takeaways: camt.057 helps banks anticipate liquidity needs

examples.title: Canceling an Inbound Notification
examples.scenario: The investor changed their mind. The £50M is not coming. The Hedge Fund cancels the pre-advice.

steps.description: Informs bank to disregard previous note.

key_takeaways: camt.058 undoes a camt.057

examples.title: Auditor Requesting Statements
examples.scenario: Auditors need bank statements from Jan 1, 2025 to Jan 31, 2025 for compliance testing.

steps.description: Submits request for specific date range.

key_takeaways: camt.060 pulls past data on demand

examples.title: Meeting a Margin Call
examples.scenario: Bank A receives a margin call due to market moves. They propose to pledge US Treasury Bonds.

steps.description: Offers US Treasuries to satisfy margin req.
steps.technical: colr.003 (Margin Call Request? No, colr.003 is Substitution. Maybe colr.001? Let's check defs. colr.003 is Substitution. colr.001 is Margin Call Request. colr.002 is Margin Call Response). Let's use Substitution scenario as planned.

key_takeaways: colr messages manage risk collateral

examples.title: Responding to Margin Call
examples.scenario: Prime Broker demands $1M margin. Hedge Fund agrees to pay cash.

steps.technical: colr.002 (Margin Call Response) agreeing to the call amount.

key_takeaways: colr.002 answers the margin demand

examples.title: Settling an FX Spot Deal
examples.scenario: Corp Treasury bought £1M vs USD for spot delivery (T+2). Sends settlement instruction.

steps.description: Details where to pay USD and where to receive GBP.

key_takeaways: fxtr.014 replaces MT300 for instructions

examples.title: Confirming an FX Forward
examples.scenario: Bank A and Bank B agree on a 3-month forward. Bank A sends confirmation request.

steps.description: Sends trade details to verify match.

key_takeaways: Automation prevents settlement risk

examples.title: FX Trade Status Update
examples.scenario: CLS Bank confirms the trade has matched and is eligible for settlement.
key_takeaways: Real-time status tracking for FX

examples.title: Bank-to-Bank Funding (Cover)
examples.scenario: SocGen needs to fund its USD nostro account at Citi to pay a customer.

steps.description: Transfers $10M to its own account at Citi.

key_takeaways: pacs.009 is for bank-to-bank moves

examples.title: Interbank Fee Collection
examples.scenario: Chase collects monthly maintenance fees from Commerzbank's account.
key_takeaways: Banks bill each other using pacs.010

examples.title: Tracking a Lost Payment
examples.scenario: Customer complains beneficiary didn't get funds sent 3 days ago. Bank Ops investigates.

steps.description: Asks Santander: 'Did you get payment UETR-123?'

steps.technical: pacs.002 (Payment Status Report) with status ACCP.

key_takeaways: pacs.028 pulls status updates

examples.title: Reversing a Duplicate Bank Transfer
examples.scenario: Intesa's system accidentally sent the same batch twice. They need to reverse the second batch.

steps.description: Requests return of funds for batch ID 999.

key_takeaways: pacs.007 undoes a pacs.008 (if not yet credited)

examples.title: Setting up a SEPA Mandate
examples.scenario: Consumer authorizes Utility Co to pull monthly bills.
key_takeaways: pain.009 digitizes paper mandates

examples.title: Amending Mandate Amount
examples.scenario: Consumer upgrades plan, authorizing higher limit.
key_takeaways: pain.010 updates existing mandates

examples.title: Canceling a Gym Subscription
examples.scenario: Member cancels gym membership and revokes payment authorization.

steps.description: Instructs bank to stop future debits.

key_takeaways: pain.011 stops direct debits

examples.title: Requesting Payment from Customer
examples.scenario: Merchant sends a 'Request to Pay' to shopper's mobile app for instant checkout.

steps.description: Bank app shows request. Shopper taps 'Pay'.
steps.technical: Result is a pacs.008 credit transfer initiated by Shopper.

key_takeaways: pain.013 is the 'Invoice' message

examples.title: Status of Payment Request
examples.scenario: Shopper rejected the Request to Pay. Bank informs Merchant.

steps.technical: pain.014 (Creditor Payment Activation Request Status Report).

key_takeaways: pain.014 closes the loop on pain.013

examples.title: Dividend Payment Notification
examples.scenario: Issuer announces dividend. CSD notifies Custodian of upcoming payment.

steps.description: Details: 0.50 EUR per share, pay date tomorrow.

key_takeaways: seev messages handle asset servicing

examples.title: Monthly Portfolio Statement
examples.scenario: End of month reporting of securities holdings.

steps.description: Lists all stocks and bonds held.

key_takeaways: semt.002 is the securities equivalent of camt.053

examples.title: Buying Stock (Delivery vs Payment)
examples.scenario: Buyer agrees to buy 100 shares of IBM for $15,000. Settlement is DVP (cash swaps for shares).
key_takeaways: sese.023 instructs the actual trade settlement

examples.title: Selling Bonds (Free of Payment)
examples.scenario: Moving bonds between internal accounts. No cash involved.
key_takeaways: sese.023 handles both DVP and FOP

examples.title: Trade Finance Invoice Submission
examples.scenario: Supplier uploads invoice data to Bank Payment Obligation (BPO) platform.

steps.description: Provides PO and Invoice data for matching.

key_takeaways: tsmt digitizes trade documentation

examples.title: Sending Detailed Remittance Advice
examples.scenario: Payer sends a check for $1M covering 500 invoices. Sends digital advice separately.

steps.description: Lists all 500 invoice numbers and amounts.
steps.technical: remt.001 (Remittance Advice). Linked to payment by reference.

key_takeaways: remt.001 sends data separately from money

examples.title: Treasury Deal Confirmation
examples.scenario: Treasury confirms a Non-Deliverable Forward (NDF) deal.

steps.technical: trea.001 (NDF opening confirmation - *Note: trea messages are rare, often fxtr is used, but trea exists*).

key_takeaways: Specialized messages for treasury products

examples.title: Complex Cross-Border Payment Investigation
examples.scenario: GlobalCorp sends a $2M payment to SupplierLtd. The funds do not arrive after 5 days. GlobalCorp launches an investigation. The payment was held at an intermediary bank due to missing compliance info, then released, but with a deducted fee that causes a short payment.

steps.description: US Corp contacts their bank because a $100,000 payment to UK Supplier hasn't arrived after 5 days.
Bank of America sends a camt.026 to trace the payment through the clearing system.
CHIPS traces the payment and forwards the investigation to Barclays in the UK.
steps.decision_question: Was the payment credited to beneficiary?

steps.description: Barclays confirms the payment was credited to UK Supplier's account on day 2.
steps.technical: camt.029 resolution with proof of credit

steps.description: CHIPS forwards the confirmation that payment was successfully credited.
Bank of America informs US Corp that payment was credited. Issue may be with UK Supplier's reconciliation.
Barclays found the payment was rejected due to account number mismatch.
Barclays initiates return of the $100,000 via pacs.004.
CHIPS processes the return and sends funds back to Bank of America.
Bank of America credits US Corp's account and advises them to verify beneficiary details before resending.

key_takeaways: Cross-border payments can get stuck at intermediaries
pacs.028/camt.029 handles investigations

examples.title: Letter of Credit Settlement with Discrepancies
examples.scenario: Exporter presents documents under LC. Issuing Bank finds discrepancies (late shipment). Importer agrees to waive discrepancies. Payment is made.

steps.description: Submits Bill of Lading and Invoice to Advising Bank (BOC).
steps.technical: Physical docs digitized or tsmt.013 (DataSet Submission).

steps.description: Finds shipment date is 1 day late. Refuses payment initially.
Needs goods urgently. Instructs bank to pay anyway.
steps.technical: tsmt.041 (Transaction Report Request? No, usually applicant instruction).

key_takeaways: Trade finance involves document matching
Payment is conditional on documents

examples.title: Mandatory Corporate Action with Choice
examples.scenario: Issuer offers dividend: Cash or Stock. Investor elects Stock.

steps.description: On pay date, credits new shares.

key_takeaways: Investors must reply with seev.033 for voluntary events

examples.title: Recall of Duplicate Bulk Payment
examples.scenario: Payroll runs the monthly file twice by mistake. 1000 payments sent. Need to recall all.

steps.technical: Multiple camt.056 (FIToFIPaymentCancellationRequest) messages sent to clearing.

steps.description: Funds not yet withdrawn. Debits customer, returns funds.

steps.technical: camt.029 (Resolution Of Investigation) with negative outcome.
key_fields: Rsn: NOAS (No Answer/No Funds? CUST decision usually)

key_takeaways: Recall success is not guaranteed

examples.title: Serial vs Cover Payment Routing
examples.scenario: Payment from Brazil (BRL) to Japan (JPY) via USD correspondents. Using Cover method to speed up message.

steps.description: Sends payment details directly to Bank B (MT103 equivalent).
steps.technical: pacs.008 (Customer Credit Transfer) sent directly to Bank B.

steps.description: Sends actual funds via US Correspondent.
steps.technical: pacs.009 (FI Credit Transfer) sent to JP Morgan (US).

steps.description: Credits Bank B's USD account or forwards to their correspondent.
steps.technical: pacs.009 forwarded to Bank B's correspondent (e.g. Citibank Tokyo).

steps.description: Receives pacs.008 (details) and pacs.009 (money). Matches them and credits customer.

key_takeaways: Cover method separates info (pacs.008) from money (pacs.009)

examples.title: Full Customer Lifecycle: Onboarding to Closure
examples.scenario: A complete journey of Startup Inc: Opening a business account, making the first payment, setting up a direct debit, receiving a client payment, and finally closing the account after being acquired.

steps.description: Startup Inc applies for a new GBP business account via API.
steps.technical: acmt.007 (Account Opening Request). Includes KYB data.

steps.description: Bank approves application and issues IBAN.
Pays incorporation fees to Companies House.
Signs mandate for cloud hosting services.
Startup Inc receives first revenue payment.
After acquisition, requests to close the account and sweep funds.
Transfers remaining balance and confirms closure.

key_takeaways: ISO 20022 covers the entire banking relationship
acmt messages manage the lifecycle states

examples.title: SEPA Instant Credit Transfer (SCT Inst)
examples.scenario: Pierre sends €50 to Hans for dinner. The payment must settle within 10 seconds across borders using the SEPA Instant scheme.

steps.technical: pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer) with Service Level 'SEPA' and Local Instrument 'INST'.

steps.description: Sends payment via TIPS (TARGET Instant Payment Settlement).
Validates account and credits Hans immediately.
steps.technical: pacs.002 (Payment Status Report) with status ACCP sent back to BNP via TIPS.

possible_errors.result: Transaction rejected if not settled in time

key_takeaways: SCT Inst requires 24/7 availability and 10s timeout

examples.title: Large Value CHIPS Payment
examples.scenario: OilCorp pays $50 Million for a crude oil shipment using CHIPS (Clearing House Interbank Payments System), utilizing its liquidity efficiency.

steps.description: Sends payment instruction to CHIPS clearing queue.
steps.technical: pacs.009 (Financial Institution Credit Transfer) - *Note: CHIPS ISO 20022 uses pacs.009/pacs.008 depending on type. For commercial, pacs.008.* Let's use pacs.008.

steps.description: CHIPS algorithm matches offsetting payments to save liquidity.
steps.technical: Internal netting process. Once funded, payment is released.

key_takeaways: CHIPS handles 95% of cross-border USD flow

examples.title: Cross-Border Tracking with SWIFT gpi
examples.scenario: Alice sends CAD to Bob (AUD). She tracks the payment as it hops through a US intermediary (USD) using the UETR.

steps.description: Assigns unique tracker ID to payment.
Converts CAD to USD, deducts fee, reports status to Tracker.
steps.technical: trck.001 (Tracker Update - *Note: often handled via API or MT199/pacs.002 in CBPR+ context*).

steps.description: Converts USD to AUD, credits Bob.

key_takeaways: UETR allows end-to-end visibility

examples.title: House Purchase via CHAPS
examples.scenario: Completion day. £450,000 must arrive by 2 PM for keys release. Uses CHAPS (RTGS).

steps.technical: pacs.008 sent to Bank of England.

steps.description: Debits Barclays, Credits NatWest in central bank money.

key_takeaways: CHAPS guarantees same-day settlement

examples.title: Weekend Bill Pay via RTP
examples.scenario: Sarah forgot her electric bill due Sunday. Pays via RTP to avoid late fees.

steps.technical: pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer) routed to RTP network.

steps.description: PowerCo receives funds instantly, bill marked paid.

key_takeaways: RTP works 24/7/365

examples.title: B2B Invoice via FedNow
examples.scenario: Bakery needs flour delivery urgently. Driver is at the dock waiting for payment confirmation.
key_takeaways: FedNow enables instant B2B commerce

examples.title: Corporate Cash Pooling (ZBA Sweep)
examples.scenario: GlobalCorp uses a Zero Balance Account (ZBA) structure. At end of day, €2.5M excess cash from the French subsidiary is automatically swept to the HQ Master Account in London to optimize interest. The subsidiary account is left with €0.

steps.description: At 17:00 CET, the system calculates the end-of-day balance for Subsidiary FR. Balance: +€2,500,000.
steps.technical: Internal balance calculation. Triggers automatic sweep instruction.

steps.description: Transfers €2.5M from Subsidiary FR to HQ Master Account.
steps.technical: pacs.009 (Financial Institution Credit Transfer) sent to HSBC London. Or internal book transfer if same entity.

steps.description: Credits HQ account. Global liquidity position updated.
steps.technical: camt.054 (Credit Notification) sent to GlobalCorp HQ Treasury System (TMS).

steps.description: Generates statement for Subsidiary showing the debit and final €0 balance.
steps.technical: camt.053 (Bank to Customer Statement) sent to Subsidiary/HQ.

key_takeaways: ZBA automates liquidity concentration
camt.053 confirms the zero close

examples.title: Corporate FX Hedging Program
examples.scenario: A US Corporation expects a €10M payment in 3 months. To hedge against EUR/USD depreciation, the Treasurer enters into a Forward Contract to sell €10M at 1.10.

steps.description: Executes trade on Bloomberg/FXall. Sell €10M Forward 3M @ 1.10.
steps.technical: Trade execution on platform. Generates trade ticket.

steps.description: TMS sends automated confirmation instruction to the bank.
Bank system matches details and sends positive confirmation.
steps.technical: fxtr.017 (Foreign Exchange Trade Confirmation Request) or fxtr.008 status match.

steps.description: 3 months later, net settlement occurs (or gross).
steps.technical: pacs.008 / pacs.009 for the cash movement.

key_takeaways: fxtr messages automate post-trade processing

examples.title: Commercial Paper Issuance
examples.scenario: Large Corp issues €50M Commercial Paper (CP) for 30 days to fund working capital. The notes are issued in dematerialized form at the CSD.

steps.description: Instructs IPA (Issuing & Paying Agent) to create €50M notes.
steps.technical: seev.031 (Corporate Action Notification) or specialized issuance message.

steps.description: Buys the CP at a discount.
steps.technical: sese.023 (Securities Settlement Transaction Instruction) DVP (Delivery vs Payment).

steps.description: Moves cash from Investor to Issuer, moves CP tokens to Investor.
Cash proceeds land in Issuer's treasury account.

key_takeaways: Treasury uses securities messages for debt issuance

examples.title: Intraday Liquidity Optimization
examples.scenario: At 11:00 AM, the Treasurer notices a short position in SGD at Bank A and a long position in SGD at Bank B. They move funds to cover the shortfall and avoid overdraft fees.

steps.description: Treasury workstation requests real-time balances from all banking partners.
steps.technical: camt.060 (Account Reporting Request) sent to Bank A and Bank B.

steps.description: Bank A reports -5M SGD (Overdraft risk). Bank B reports +20M SGD.
Moves 6M SGD from Bank B to Bank A to cover hole + buffer.
steps.technical: pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer) sent to Bank B.

steps.description: Sends urgent wire to Bank A.
Receives credit alert from Bank A.

key_takeaways: Real-time visibility (camt.052) prevents overdrafts

examples.title: Repo Trade Lifecycle (Repurchase Agreement)
examples.scenario: Barclays Treasury needs overnight liquidity. They borrow £100M cash from BlackRock, pledging UK Gilts as collateral. Next day, they repay £100M + Interest and get bonds back.

steps.description: Agrees to borrow £100M vs Gilts. Sends settlement instruction.
Sends matching instruction (Receive Gilts, Pay Cash).
Moves Bonds to BlackRock, Cash to Barclays.

key_takeaways: Repos are key for short-term treasury funding

examples.title: Bank Internal Liquidity Transfer (MT200)
examples.scenario: Barclays London Treasury needs to move $50M USD from its account at JPMorgan NY to its own branch account at Barclays New York for overnight funding. This is a Financial Institution Transfer for Own Account (formerly MT200).

steps.description: Instructs JPMorgan NY to move $50M to Barclays NY.
steps.technical: pacs.009 (Financial Institution Credit Transfer). Settlement Priority: HIGH.

steps.description: Debits Barclays London's account and sends funds via Fedwire/CHIPS to Barclays NY.
steps.technical: pacs.009 sent to clearing system (or internal book transfer if JPM clears for Barclays NY).
camt.054 (Credit Notification) or pacs.002 confirmation to London.

key_takeaways: pacs.009 CORE is used for bank-to-bank transfers
Replaces MT200/MT202 for own account moves

examples.title: Global Market Mixed-Traffic Simulation (Expanded)
examples.scenario: A comprehensive stress test across the ISO 20022 landscape. This simulation validates the processing of Payments (pacs/pain), Securities Settlement (sese), Investment Funds (setr), Account Management (acmt), System Administration (admi), FX Trades (fxtr), and Cash Management (camt) in a single high-volume stream.

Trade instruction for Apple Inc. shares.
HedgeFund X subscribes to a mutual fund.

HedgeFund X subscribes to a mutual fund.

possible_errors.result: Messages queued or rejected with admi.002

key_takeaways: ISO 20022 covers the entire financial lifecycle, not just payments
setr messages handle the complexity of mutual fund subscriptions
admi messages are critical for system-level communication (maintenance, rejects)
acmt provides standardized workflows for opening and maintaining accounts

examples.title: Global Corporate Treasury Operations - Full Day Lifecycle
examples.scenario: A comprehensive full-day simulation of GlobalCorp's treasury operations across multiple time zones. Starting with Asia-Pacific morning liquidity management, through European midday trading, to US afternoon settlements. Covers payment initiation, FX trading, securities settlement, card processing, corporate actions, collateral management, and regulatory reporting. Demonstrates how ISO 20022 messages orchestrate complex multi-entity financial operations.

steps.description: Singapore treasury starts the day requesting real-time balance at 8:00 AM SGT.
DBS responds with current position showing SGD 15.2M available.
Request EOD statement from previous business day for reconciliation.
Full previous day statement with 47 transactions.
Notify Japanese customer about upcoming payment due.
Japanese customer initiates payment for invoice.
MUFG confirms payment accepted for processing.
MUFG routes cross-border payment through SWIFT.
DBS acknowledges receipt of incoming payment.
Request new account for Vietnam subsidiary.
Request spot FX quote for USD/SGD.
Accept and execute FX trade at quoted rate.
Confirmation of FX trade with settlement details.
Report new FX position to custodian.
Report consolidated Asia-Pacific position to HQ.
Route payment to Bank of China.
Frankfurt treasury requests morning balance at 8:00 AM CET.
Deutsche Bank provides current EUR position.
Initiate SEPA credit transfer to German supplier.
Confirm SEPA payment submitted to clearing.
Request to increase DD mandate limit.
Instruct EUR 5M German bond purchase settlement.
Bank resolves case - found in suspense.
Report consolidated EU position to HQ.
US treasury requests morning position at 8:00 AM EST.
JP Morgan provides consolidated USD position.
Send high-value wire to Chinese supplier.
JP Morgan confirms wire accepted for Fedwire.
Submit payment to Fedwire for immediate settlement.
Fed settles payment to Bank of China correspondent.
Bank of China confirms Fedwire receipt.
Bank submits payroll to ACH network.
Submit to CHIPS for multilateral netting.
Request FX quote for EUR receipts.
Book non-deliverable forward for BRL hedge.
Visa sends batch of corporate card transactions.
Bank notifies of card settlement debit.
Real-time card auth for large purchase.
Apply for documentary letter of credit.

key_takeaways: Global treasury operations span multiple time zones requiring 24-hour coverage
ISO 20022 provides a unified messaging standard across all financial domains
Real-time gross settlement (RTGS) enables same-day high-value payments
Direct debit mandates require careful management and customer consent
Securities settlement follows T+1 or T+2 cycles requiring advance planning
FX trades require T+2 settlement with proper SSI management
Collateral management is critical for managing counterparty risk
Card processing involves multiple message types for authorization and settlement
Regulatory reporting is mandatory and increasingly automated
End-of-day reconciliation ensures all positions are accurate
Payment investigations use standardized case management messages
